<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Year Ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 Compared to Year Ended February&nbsp;2, 2008.  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET REVENUE.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net revenue for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 increased by $343.5&nbsp;million, or 19.6%, to $2,093.4&nbsp;million, from
$1,749.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. All segments contributed to this revenue growth with double-digit percentage increases. The largest contribution to this revenue
growth was generated by our European segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased by $115.6&nbsp;million, or 13.4%, to $978.0&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $862.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was driven by an average of 55 net additional stores during the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, resulting in a 12.8% increase in average square
footage compared to the prior year, and an increase in comparable store sales of 1.0% in fiscal 2009 compared to fiscal 2008. Currency translation fluctuations relating to our Canadian retail stores
unfavorably impacted revenues by $9.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased by $37.8&nbsp;million, or 14.6%, to $296.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $258.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The revenue growth was generated from our expanding Asia operations, primarily in South Korea and Greater China. During fiscal year 2009, the Company, along with
its partners, opened 20 stores and 31 concessions in Greater China and 10 stores and 29 concessions in South Korea. Our U.S. wholesale products, which are mostly sold through better department stores,
were sold in approximately 1,057
major doors as of January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to 1,006 major doors at the end of the prior year period. Currency translation fluctuations, relating to both our Canadian and South Korean
operations, unfavorably impacted net revenue in our wholesale segment by $16.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased by $180.6&nbsp;million, or 33.5%, to $719.0&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $538.4&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. All of our wholesale businesses in Europe contributed to this growth, including BARN, which we acquired in January </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=41,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=235271,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_39"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>2008.
The growth is also attributable to same store sales growth in our existing retail stores and the addition of new retail stores, increasing our directly operated store count to 61 stores at
January&nbsp;31, 2009 from 40 stores at February&nbsp;2, 2008. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $34.7&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our European
operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalty revenue from licensing operations increased by $9.6&nbsp;million, or 10.5%, to $100.3&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $90.7&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was the result of the strength of the accessories business, particularly watches, jewelry, footwear, eyewear and handbags. Licensing revenues
in fiscal year 2009 did not include any royalty revenue from our BARN business which we now operate directly as part of our European operations. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;GROSS PROFIT.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit increased by $129.8&nbsp;million, or 16.4%, to $922.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from
$792.8&nbsp;million for the prior period. The increase in gross profit primarily resulted from the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the retail segment increased by $14.7&nbsp;million, or 4.5%, to $344.8&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $330.1&nbsp;million for the prior period, primarily due to higher unit sales volume driven by the expansion in our store count during the year and an increase in
comparable store sales of 1.0% compared to the prior year. The increase in gross profit also includes the unfavorable impact of higher occupancy costs due to the store expansion and lower product
margins.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the wholesale segment decreased by $1.5&nbsp;million, or 1.5%, to $97.9&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $99.4&nbsp;million for the prior year period, primarily due to lower product margins in our North American wholesale operations and increased occupancy costs in
Asia, partially offset by higher sales volume in our Asian operations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the European operations increased by $107.0&nbsp;million, or 39.3%, to $379.6&nbsp;million for the
year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $272.6&nbsp;million for the prior year period. The increase in our European gross profit was primarily attributable to higher sales volume in the existing
European wholesale and retail operations, higher wholesale product margins and the impact of the acquisitions of BARN in January 2008 and Focus Spain in October 2007.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the licensing segment increased by $9.6&nbsp;million, or 10.5%, to $100.3&nbsp;million for the year
ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $90.7&nbsp;million for the prior year period. The licensing gross profit improvement resulted from higher sales by our licensees of accessory and footwear
products. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin (gross profit as a percentage of total net revenues) decreased 120 basis points to 44.1% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from 45.3% for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008. The decline in the overall gross margin was attributable to lower product margins in our retail and wholesale segments, partially offset by higher product margins in Europe
and a higher mix of European net revenues, which generated a relatively higher gross margin than the other segments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margin may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A expenses increased by $110.2&nbsp;million, or 22.8%, to $593.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009, from $483.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. About $46.1&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to higher store selling, merchandising and
distribution costs due to the higher sales volumes. Approximately $36.1&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to spending to support newer businesses, including BARN, Focus Spain, our G by
GUESS brand, and Greater China, as well as spending to support the continued build-out of our European </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=42,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=157964,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_40"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>headquarters
in Lugano, Switzerland. In addition, approximately $24.4&nbsp;million of asset impairment charges were recorded during fiscal year 2009 compared to $0.6&nbsp;million in the prior
year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a percentage of net revenues, SG&amp;A expense increased to 28.4% for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to 27.6% for prior year period, driven by additional spending for
infrastructure and new businesses in Europe and the asset impairment charges, partially offset by expense leverage in our wholesale segment and in our corporate overhead. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings from operations increased by $19.7&nbsp;million, or 6.4%, to $328.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to earnings from operations of $309.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the retail segment were $93.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to earnings from operations of $128.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The decrease was driven by the store impairment charges of $23.3&nbsp;million and the impact
of lower product margins. This was partially offset by higher sales and the resulting gross profit due to the larger store base, and lower advertising and marketing costs. Currency translation
fluctuations relating to our Canadian retail stores unfavorably impacted earnings from operations by $1.7&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment were $45.5&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to earnings from operations of $49.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. While segment revenues increased, the decrease in earnings from operations was driven by lower
segment product margins and higher occupancy and SG&amp;A expenses to support our expanding Asian operations. Currency translation fluctuations, relating to both our Canadian and South Korean operations,
unfavorably impacted earnings from operations in our wholesale segment by $2.5&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the European segment were $168.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $120.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was primarily due to the higher sales and gross profit resulting from growth in our existing European
wholesale businesses, and our acquisition of BARN. This increase was partially offset by higher volume related operating costs and infrastructure spending, along with higher advertising and marketing
costs. Currency translation fluctuations favorably impacted earnings from operations in our European segment by $9.7&nbsp;million.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the licensing segment were $86.4&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $77.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase was the result of higher revenues generated by our product licensees. This increase was partially offset by
the loss of royalty revenue from BARN, our kids product licensee, which we acquired and now report as part of our European operations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Unallocated corporate overhead, included in SG&amp;A, was $64.9&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
compared to $68.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, mainly due to lower compensation related costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
lower gross margin and higher SG&amp;A expenses as a percentage of net revenues resulted in a decrease in operating margin of 200 basis points to 15.7% for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009 from 17.7% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense increased to $4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to
$3.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, primarily due to higher average debt balances in Europe to support working capital growth. On a comparable basis, the average debt
balance for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 was $59.2&nbsp;million versus an average debt balance of $48.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Interest income decreased
to $6.1&nbsp;million for the year </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=43,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=368061,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_41"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, due to lower interest rates on invested cash, partially offset by higher average invested cash
balances. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;OTHER EXPENSE, NET.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense was $11.3&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, versus other expense of $1.8&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Other expense for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 primarily resulted from the decline in value of insurance policy investments and other
non-operating assets. For the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, other expense included a net charge of $0.3&nbsp;million relating to changes in foreign exchange rates on foreign
currency forward contracts and other foreign currency transactions. The forward contracts are used to hedge currency exposure primarily relating to U.S. dollar transactions in our foreign operations
in the event of a strengthening U.S. dollar. The impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar on the forward contracts during the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 resulted in a
mark-to-market gain of $18.8&nbsp;million. This gain was primarily offset by the unfavorable revaluation of U.S. dollar denominated liabilities in our foreign operations of
$18.5&nbsp;million during the same period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INCOME TAXES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 was $103.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a 32.6% effective tax rate,
compared to income tax expense for the prior year of $124.1&nbsp;million, or a 39.8% effective tax rate. The lower tax rate in fiscal year 2009 was due to a higher mix of profits in lower tax
jurisdictions and a decline in the Italian statutory tax rate at the end of fiscal 2008 that resulted in a devaluation of our Italian deferred tax assets at the end of fiscal year 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;MINORITY INTEREST.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The minority interest expense for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 was $1.5&nbsp;million, net of taxes, as compared to
minority interest expense of $0.9&nbsp;million, net of taxes, for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase in minority interest expense was primarily due to the stronger performance of
Focus and our Mexican joint venture. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;NET EARNINGS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings increased by $27.1&nbsp;million, or 14.5%, to $213.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, from
$186.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. Diluted earnings per share increased to $2.28 per share for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to $1.99 per share for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Year Ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 Compared to Year Ended February&nbsp;3, 2007.  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;NET REVENUE.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net revenue for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 increased by $497.2&nbsp;million, or 39.7%, to $1,749.9&nbsp;million,
from $1,252.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. All segments contributed to this revenue growth with double-digit percentage increases. The largest contribution to this
revenue growth was generated by our European segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased by $121.3&nbsp;million, or 16.4%, to $862.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $741.1&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was driven by a comparable store sales growth of 14.6% and an average of 26 net additional stores during the fiscal year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008 resulting in a 5.3% increase in average square footage compared to the prior year period. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $14.3&nbsp;million of the increase
in net revenue relating to our Canadian retail stores. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased by $105.8&nbsp;million, or 69.3%, to $258.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $152.6&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately 80.0% of this revenue growth was generated outside of the U.S., primarily in Asia. Our North American wholesale net revenue growth was
primarily attributable to strong product performance. Our products were sold in the U.S. in approximately 1,006 major doors as of February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 961 major doors at the end of the
prior year period. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $2.8&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our Canadian wholesale business. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=44,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=58054,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased by $246.6&nbsp;million, or 84.5%, to $538.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $291.8&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The majority of the revenue growth was generated by the European wholesale business, driven by our continued growth in both our existing accessories and
apparel businesses and our acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus on December&nbsp;31, 2006. The growth is also attributable to same store sales growth in our existing retail stores and the
addition of new retail stores. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $48.1&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our European operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalty revenue from licensing operations increased by $23.6&nbsp;million, or 35.1%, to $90.7&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$67.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was the result of the strength of the accessories business, particularly handbags, footwear and watches, and the increased
recognition of licensing revenues as a result of the amortization of fixed cash rights payments received from licensees in connection with previously renegotiated contracts based on the periods these
contracts represent. Licensing revenues in fiscal 2008 did not include any royalty revenue from our GUESS by MARCIANO and South Korean licensees, both of which we now operate directly, as the
associated sales are now reported as revenue in the European and wholesale segments, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;GROSS PROFIT.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross profit increased by $240.3&nbsp;million, or 43.5%, to $792.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008,
from $552.5&nbsp;million in the prior period. The increase in gross profit primarily resulted from sales growth in all segments.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the retail segment increased by $50.2&nbsp;million, or 17.9%, to $330.1&nbsp;million for the fiscal
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $279.9&nbsp;million in the prior period, primarily due to higher sales volume and higher average selling prices, partially offset by higher occupancy costs. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the wholesale segment increased by $44.1&nbsp;million, or 79.6%, to $99.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $55.3&nbsp;million in the prior year period, primarily due to the increase in sales volume in Asia, and increased sales and higher mark-ups in
North America driven by stronger product performance.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the European operations increased by $122.4&nbsp;million, or 81.5%, to $272.6&nbsp;million for the
fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $150.2&nbsp;million in the prior year period. The European gross profit increase resulted from higher sales volumes in the existing European
operations and the acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus at the end of 2006.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit for the licensing segment increased by $23.6&nbsp;million, or 35.1%, to $90.7&nbsp;million for the fiscal
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $67.1&nbsp;million in the prior year period. The licensing gross profit improvement was primarily the result of the strong sales performance of accessories,
especially handbags, footwear and watches. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin (gross profit as a percentage of total net revenues) increased 120 basis points to 45.3% for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from 44.1% for the year ended
February&nbsp;3, 2007. The improvement in the overall gross margin was attributable to a higher mix of European net revenues, which generated a relatively higher gross margin than the other
businesses, higher mark-ups in our wholesale segment, and higher product margins in our retail segment due to higher mark-ups and gift card breakage income. This improvement
was partially offset by the lower product margin in Europe compared to the prior year. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margin may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A expenses increased by $136.6&nbsp;million, or 39.4%, to $483.6&nbsp;million for the fiscal
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $347.0&nbsp;million </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=45,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=686068,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_43"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>for
the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately $68.0&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to incremental spending required to support new businesses including Focus, our new
European headquarters in Lugano, Switzerland, the new G by GUESS brand initiative, the South Korea operation, expansion in Greater China and Mexico, and BARN in Europe. In addition, the increase was
also attributable to growth in store selling, merchandising and distribution costs of $41.8&nbsp;million, incremental compensation expenses (primarily performance-based) of $12.5&nbsp;million, and
additional advertising and marketing spending in our existing businesses of $8.3&nbsp;million. As a percentage of net revenue, SG&amp;A expenses improved to 27.6% for the fiscal year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 27.7% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings from operations increased by $103.6&nbsp;million, or 50.4%, to $309.1&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared with earnings from operations of $205.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the retail segment were $128.5&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, compared to earnings from operations of $105.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase in earnings from operations for the retail segment was driven by the higher
sales volume, higher product margin and occupancy leverage, partially offset by increased investments in infrastructure to support our new G by GUESS brand concept and higher advertising expense.
Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $3.5&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our Canadian retail stores.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment were $49.9&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, compared to earnings from operations of $25.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase was principally due to incremental sales and gross profit from our new
South Korea operation and higher sales and improved gross profit in North America, partially offset by additional SG&amp;A expenses in Asia, including South Korea, to build infrastructure in this region
and support the increased sales. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $0.8&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our Canadian wholesale business. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the European segment were $120.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, compared to $73.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was primarily due to higher sales and gross profit in the existing accessories and apparel wholesale
businesses combined with the sales and gross profit resulting from our acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus in late 2006. In addition, our existing Company-owned retail business in Europe
continued to improve, generating strong sales growth and increasing profits. The growth in sales and gross profit was partially offset by higher volume related and infrastructure expansion expenses.
Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $10.4&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our European operations.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations for the licensing segment were $77.9&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, compared to $58.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The improvement was the result of higher revenues generated by our accessories product licensees and the recognition
of additional licensing revenues relating to the amortization of fixed cash rights payments received from licensees in connection with previously renegotiated contracts. These increases were partially
offset by the loss of royalty revenue from the GUESS by MARCIANO and South Korean licensees in fiscal 2008 compared to fiscal 2007.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Unallocated corporate overhead was $68.0&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to
$57.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, mainly due to higher performance-based compensation costs, including share based payment expense. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=46,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=553161,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_44"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
higher gross margin and lower SG&amp;A spending as a percentage of net revenues resulted in an increase in operating margin of 130 basis points to 17.7% for the fiscal year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008 from 16.4% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense decreased to $3.4&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared
to $7.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, primarily due to the early redemption of the Company's 6.75% Secured Notes of $32.8&nbsp;million at the end of 2006. The Secured
Notes were redeemed in December 2006 resulting in a $1.4&nbsp;million write-off of debt issuance costs and a $0.5&nbsp;million redemption premium, which are included in interest
expense for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. On a comparable basis, the average debt balance for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was $48.6&nbsp;million versus an average debt
balance of $79.4&nbsp;million, for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Interest income increased to $7.5&nbsp;million for the
fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $6.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, due to higher average invested cash balances. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;OTHER INCOME, NET.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense, net was $1.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, versus other income, net of
$4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Other expense, net in the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was primarily due to net losses related to changes in foreign
exchange rates on forward contracts and other foreign currency transactions. Other income, net in the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 comprised gains on sale of land and other long-term
investments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;INCOME TAXES.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was $124.1&nbsp;million, or a 39.8% effective tax rate, compared
to income tax expense of $77.6&nbsp;million, or a 37.2% effective tax rate, for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Fiscal 2008's higher tax rate was due to a higher mix of profits in higher tax
jurisdictions, the utilization of capital loss carryforwards in the prior year, favorable tax audit settlements last year and a recent decline in the Italian statutory tax rate, effective in fiscal
2009, that resulted in a devaluation of deferred tax assets in the fiscal 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> &nbsp;MINORITY INTEREST.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The minority interest expense of $0.9&nbsp;million, net of taxes, primarily represents the portion of earnings of Focus for the
fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 allocated to the minority interest stockholders. The Company acquired a 75% interest in Focus on December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;NET EARNINGS.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net earnings increased by $55.3&nbsp;million, or 42.2%, to $186.5&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008,
from $131.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Diluted earnings per share increased to $1.99 per share for the fiscal year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 compared to $1.42 per
share for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> One-Month Audited Transition Period Ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 ("January 2007") Compared to the One-Month Unaudited Period Ended
January&nbsp;28, 2006 ("January 2006").  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reported net earnings of $8.0&nbsp;million, or diluted earnings of $0.09 per share, for January 2007 (which included
34&nbsp;days), compared to $0.00 per share for January
2006 (which included 28&nbsp;days). Net revenue for January 2007 increased by $67.5&nbsp;million, or 98.6%, to $136.0&nbsp;million, from $68.5&nbsp;million for January 2006. Gross profit
increased by $33.1&nbsp;million, or 146.6%, to $55.7&nbsp;million for January 2007, from $22.6&nbsp;million for January 2006. SG&amp;A expenses increased by $20.6&nbsp;million, or 91.2%, to
$43.3&nbsp;million for January 2007, from $22.6&nbsp;million for January 2006. Earnings from operations increased by $12.5&nbsp;million to $12.5&nbsp;million for January 2007, compared to the
approximately break-even results from operations for January 2006. These results reflect the impact of the significant growth in our existing European operations, the comparable store
sales growth of 12.7% in our retail store operations in North America for January 2007 compared to the prior-year period, the greater number of days in the one month ended January 2007
compared to the prior-year period and the acquisition of a 75% majority interest in Focus, our European GUESS by MARCIANO licensee, in late 2006. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=47,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=220705,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_45"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We need liquidity primarily to fund our working capital in Europe, the expansion and remodeling of our retail stores,
shop-in-shop programs, systems, infrastructure, other existing operations, international growth, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases and payment of dividends to
our stockholders. During the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company relied on trade credit, available cash, short-term borrowings from its European bank facilities, real estate
leases and internally generated funds to finance its operations and expansion. The Company anticipates that it will be able to satisfy its ongoing cash requirements during the next twelve months for
working capital, capital expenditures, interest and principal payments on its debt, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases and dividend payments to stockholders, primarily with cash flow
from operations supplemented by borrowings, if necessary, under the Credit Facility and bank facilities in Europe, as described below under "&#151;Credit Facilities." As of January&nbsp;31,
2009, the Company had cash and cash equivalents of $294.1&nbsp;million. Excess cash and cash equivalents, which represent the majority of our outstanding cash and cash equivalents balance, are held
primarily in three diversified money market funds. The funds, each of which is rated AAA by national credit rating agencies, are generally comprised of high-quality, liquid instruments. As
of January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company does not have any exposure to auction-rate security investments in these funds. Please see "&#151;Important Factors Regarding Forward-Looking
Statements" and "Part&nbsp;I, ITEM 1A. Risk Factors" for a discussion of risk factors which could reasonably be likely to result in a decrease of internally generated funds available to finance
capital expenditures and working capital requirements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has presented below the cash flow performance comparison of the 2009 fiscal year versus the 2008 fiscal year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Operating Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities was $228.6&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to
$180.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, or an increase of $47.8&nbsp;million. The majority of the increase was driven by a $27.1&nbsp;million growth in net income for the
year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 versus the prior year. The remaining increase was due to working capital changes which reflected the lower growth in accounts receivable and inventory, mostly offset
by a decline in accounts payable and accrued expenses when comparing the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 to the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had working capital (including cash and cash equivalents) of $558.3&nbsp;million compared to $432.6&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008.
The Company's primary working capital needs are for inventory and accounts receivable. Accounts receivable at January&nbsp;31, 2009 amounted to $264.3&nbsp;million, an increase of
$9.9&nbsp;million, from $254.4&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase in accounts receivable was primarily due to growth in accounts receivable related to our European wholesale
business (including our new GUESS Kids business acquired in January 2008), which totaled $193.4&nbsp;million at January&nbsp;31, 2009, versus $183.6&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008.
Fluctuations in currency rates resulted in a $34.5&nbsp;million decrease to the accounts receivable balance as of January&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to the prior year end. Approximately
$159.0&nbsp;million of our European, U.S. and Canadian receivables, or 60% of the $264.3&nbsp;million in accounts receivable at January&nbsp;31, 2009, were insured for collection purposes or
subject to certain bank guarantees. Inventory at January&nbsp;31, 2009 amounted to $239.7&nbsp;million, up $7.5&nbsp;million compared to $232.2&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008. Most of
this inventory increase was related to anticipated sales growth in our existing European operations. The current year's inventory balance includes a negative translation impact of approximately
$26.6&nbsp;million due to currency fluctuations compared to the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Investing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in investing activities decreased to $102.2&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to
$117.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, or a decrease of $15.0&nbsp;million. Cash used in investing activities relates primarily to capital expenditures incurred on new
store openings and existing </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=48,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=466857,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_46"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>store
remodeling programs in the U.S. and Canada, expansion in Europe and Asia, investments in information systems and other enhancements. The decrease in net cash used in investing activities in
fiscal year 2009 was driven by lower capital expenditures relating to the opening of 57 new stores in North America during the 2009 fiscal year compared to the combination of opening 49 new stores and
converting 20 existing stores to the new G by GUESS concept in the prior year. The decrease in capital expenditures was partially offset by the net proceeds received related to the assignment of an
aircraft purchase agreement in fiscal 2008. The Company ultimately did not acquire the corporate aircraft and as a result assigned its aircraft purchase right in exchange for a payment to the Company
during the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Financing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in financing activities increased to $99.1&nbsp;million for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to
$0.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. The increase in net cash used in financing activities was primarily due to the repurchase under the Company's 2008 Share Repurchase
Program of 2.9&nbsp;million shares of the Company's common stock at a total cost of $60.5&nbsp;million, the repayment of borrowings during the current year and the higher dividend payments
compared to the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Contractual Obligations and Commitments  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes the Company's contractual obligations at January&nbsp;31, 2009 and the effects such obligations are
expected to have on liquidity and cash flow in future periods (dollars in thousands): </FONT></P>

interest on long-term debt and capital lease obligations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Does
not include insurance, taxes and common area maintenance charges. In fiscal 2009, these variable charges totaled $42.5&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
expected payments associated with the deferred compensation plan and the Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan through fiscal 2037.

FIN&nbsp;48 tax liabilities. The Company is unable to determine when these open items will be resolved. For purposes of this table, the full
FIN&nbsp;48 liability has been included in payments due in 1-3&nbsp;years.

of standby letters of credit for guarantee of foreign subsidiary's borrowings, workers' compensation and general liability insurance. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=49,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=817538,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->

HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Capital Expenditures  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross capital expenditures totaled $90.0&nbsp;million, before deducting lease incentives of $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009. This compares to gross capital expenditures of $100.2&nbsp;million, before deducting lease incentives of $11.0&nbsp;million, for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008.
The Company's capital expenditures for the full fiscal year 2010 are planned at approximately $75.4&nbsp;million (before deducting estimated lease incentives of approximately $5.4&nbsp;million)
primarily for retail store expansion in the U.S. and Canada, store remodeling programs, expansion in Europe and Asia, investments in information systems and enhancements in other infrastructure. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company evaluates strategic acquisitions and alliances and pursues those that we believe will support and contribute to our overall growth initiatives. The combined purchase price
for Focus and Focus Spain was finalized in October 2007 in the amount of &euro;19.4&nbsp;million ($25.6&nbsp;million) which included an initial payment of
&euro;10.0&nbsp;million in cash, &euro;2.0 in GUESS? common stock and &euro;7.4 in final payments after resolving certain purchase price adjustments and other
contingencies with the seller. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;16, 2008, the Company, through a subsidiary, acquired 100% of the capital stock of BARN for a purchase price of approximately
&euro;5.0&nbsp;million ($7.4&nbsp;million). The acquisition included inventory, trade receivables, payables, debt and certain long term assets used to operate the business including
leasehold interests related to four GUESS Kids stores. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Credit Facilities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;19, 2006, the Company and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a credit facility led by Bank of America, N.A.,
as administrative agent for the lenders (the "Credit Facility"). The Credit Facility provides for an $85&nbsp;million revolving multicurrency line of credit and is available for direct borrowings
and the issuance of letters of credit, subject to certain letters of credit sub-limits. The Credit Facility is scheduled to mature on September&nbsp;30, 2011. At January&nbsp;31, 2009,
the Company had $25.0&nbsp;million in outstanding standby letters of credit, $12.4&nbsp;million in
outstanding documentary letters of credit and no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Facility. See Note&nbsp;8 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further information regarding the
terms of the Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company, through its European subsidiaries, maintains short-term borrowing agreements, primarily for working capital purposes, with various banks in Europe. Under these
agreements, which are generally secured by specific accounts receivable balances, the Company can borrow up to $215.6&nbsp;million, limited primarily by accounts receivable balances at the time of
borrowing, except for one borrowing agreement which is partially secured by a $10.0&nbsp;million standby letter of credit issued under the Company's Credit Facility. Based on the applicable accounts
receivable balances at January&nbsp;31, 2009 and the standby letter of credit, the Company could have borrowed up to approximately $201.4&nbsp;million under these agreements. However, the
Company's ability to borrow outside the Credit Facility through foreign subsidiaries is generally limited to $185.0&nbsp;million under the terms of the Credit Facility. At January&nbsp;31, 2009,
the Company had $22.3&nbsp;million of outstanding borrowings and $5.6&nbsp;million in outstanding documentary letters of credit under these agreements. The agreements are primarily denominated in
Euros, have no financial ratio covenants and provide for annual interest rates ranging from 1.9% to 6.1%. The maturities of the short-term borrowings are generally linked to the credit
terms of the underlying accounts receivable that secure the borrowings. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company entered into a capital lease in December 2005 for a new building in Florence, Italy. This transaction resulted in a capital lease obligation of $16.3&nbsp;million as of
January&nbsp;31, 2009. The Company entered into a separate interest rate swap agreement designated as a non-hedging instrument resulting in a swap fixed rate of 3.55%. This interest rate
swap agreement matures in 2016 and converts the nature of the capital lease obligation from Euribor floating rate debt to fixed rate debt. The fair value of the interest rate swap liability as of
January&nbsp;31, 2009 was approximately $0.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From
time to time the Company will obtain other short term financing in foreign countries for working capital to finance its local operations. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Dividend Policy  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of fiscal 2008, the Company announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.06 per share on the Company's common
stock. Since that time, the
Company has continued to pay a quarterly cash dividend which has subsequently increased to $0.10 per share. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
continuation of this practice, on March&nbsp;17, 2009, the Company announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.10 per share on the Company's common stock. The dividend will be payable
on April&nbsp;17, 2009 to stockholders of record at the close of business on April&nbsp;1, 2009. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
payment of cash dividends in the future will be at the discretion of our Board of Directors and will be based upon a number of business, legal and other considerations, including our
cash flow from operations, capital expenditures, debt service requirements, cash paid for income taxes, earnings, share repurchases and liquidity. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Share Repurchases  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2008, the Company's Board of Directors terminated the previously authorized 2001 share repurchase program and authorized the
new 2008 Share Repurchase Program to repurchase, from time-to-time and as market and business conditions warrant, up to $200&nbsp;million of the Company's common stock.
Repurchases may be made on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions, pursuant to Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 trading plans or other available means. There is no minimum or maximum
number of shares to be repurchased under the program and the program may be discontinued at any time, without prior notice. During the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company purchased
2.9&nbsp;million shares of its common stock in open market transactions at a cost of $60.5&nbsp;million (at an average price of $21.23). At January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had remaining
authority under the 2008 Share Repurchase Program to purchase an additional $139.5&nbsp;million of its common stock. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Other  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On August&nbsp;23, 2005, the Board of Directors of the Company adopted a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan ("SERP") which became
effective January&nbsp;1, 2006. The SERP provides select employees who satisfy certain eligibility requirements with certain benefits upon retirement, termination of employment, death, disability or
a change in control of the Company, in certain prescribed circumstances. The initial participants in the SERP are Maurice Marciano, Chairman of the Board, Paul Marciano, Chief Executive Officer and
Vice Chairman of the Board, and Carlos Alberini, President and Chief Operating Officer. As a non-qualified pension plan, no funding of the SERP is required; however, the Company expects to
make annual payments into an insurance policy held in a rabbi trust to fund the expected obligations arising under the SERP. The cash surrender value of the insurance policy was $12.1&nbsp;million
and $13.3&nbsp;million as of January&nbsp;31, 2009 and
February&nbsp;2, 2008, respectively, and is included in other assets. The amount of future payments may vary, depending on the future years of service, future annual compensation of the participants
and investment performance of the trust. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January 2002, the Company established a qualified employee stock purchase plan ("ESPP"), the terms of which allow for qualified employees (as defined) to participate in the purchase
of designated shares of the Company's common stock at a price equal to 85% of the lower of the closing price at the beginning or end of each quarterly stock purchase period. On January&nbsp;23,
2002, the Company filed with the SEC a Registration Statement on Form&nbsp;S-8 registering 4,000,000 shares of common stock for the ESPP. During the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009,
67,917 shares of the Company's common stock were issued out of its treasury pursuant to the ESPP at an average price of $26.03 per share for a total of $1.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> SEASONALITY  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's business is impacted by the general seasonal trends characteristic of the apparel and retail industries. U.S. retail
operations are generally stronger from July through December, and U.S. wholesale operations generally experience stronger performance in July, August and September. The European operations are largely
wholesale driven and operate with two primary selling seasons. Spring/Summer primarily ships in January, February and March and Fall/Winter primarily ships in July, August and September. The remaining
months of the year are relatively small shipping months in Europe, primarily for reorders. The Company's goal is to reduce these seasonal effects in Europe by shipping product to customers more evenly
throughout the year and benefit from reorders later in each season. Due to the seasonality of the business, the results for any particular quarter may not be indicative of results for the full year. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> INFLATION  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not believe that the relatively moderate rates of inflation experienced in the U.S. and Europe over the last three
years have had a significant effect on net revenue or profitability. Although higher rates of inflation have been experienced in Asia where some of the Company's products are manufactured and sold,
management does not believe that foreign rates of inflation have had a material adverse effect on the Company's net revenue or profitability. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> IMPACT OF RECENT ACCOUNTING PRONOUNCEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;157 ("SFAS&nbsp;157"), "Fair Value Measurement," which defines fair value,
establishes a framework for measuring fair value in accordance with GAAP and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The provisions of SFAS&nbsp;157 are effective for fiscal years
beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007. In February 2008, the FASB issued FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-1 and FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-2. FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-1 amends
SFAS&nbsp;157 to exclude SFAS No.&nbsp;13, "Accounting for Leases," and its related interpretive accounting pronouncements that address leasing transactions. FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-2 will
delay the effective date of SFAS&nbsp;157 for all nonfinancial assets and nonfinancial liabilities, except those that are recognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements on a
recurring basis (at least annually). FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-2 partially defers the effective date of SFAS&nbsp;157 to fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2008, and interim
periods within those fiscal years for items within the scope of FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-2. The Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;157 effective February&nbsp;3, 2008 for all financial assets and
liabilities as required. Refer to Note&nbsp;18, Fair Value Measurements, of the Company's consolidated financial statements for additional information. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;157 did not have a
material impact on the Company's financial position or results of operations. The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption FSP SFAS&nbsp;157-2 on the
Company's consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;159 ("SFAS&nbsp;159"), "The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities," which permits entities to voluntarily
choose to measure many financial instruments and certain other items at fair value. SFAS&nbsp;159 provides entities an opportunity to mitigate volatility in reported earnings that is caused by
measuring related assets and liabilities differently without having to apply complex hedge accounting provisions. SFAS&nbsp;159 is effective for fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007
and was effective for the Company beginning on February&nbsp;3, 2008. SFAS&nbsp;159 allows the Company to elect the fair value option on an instrument by instrument basis. SFAS&nbsp;159 did not
have an impact on the Company's consolidated results of operations or financial condition as the Company did not elect to adopt the fair value option for any of its financial assets or liabilities. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007) ("SFAS&nbsp;141R"), "Business Combinations," which replaces FASB Statement 141. SFAS&nbsp;141R establishes
principles and requirements for how an acquirer recognizes and measures in its financial statements the identifiable assets acquired, the liabilities assumed, any noncontrolling interest in the
acquiree and the goodwill acquired. SFAS&nbsp;141R also </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=12,SEQ=52,EFW="2191813",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=912518,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK125:[09ZAB1.09ZAB45001]DO45001A.;9',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='31-MAR-2009;11:59' -->
<A NAME="page_do45001_1_50"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>modifies
the recognition for preacquisition contingencies, such as environmental or legal issues, restructuring plans and acquired research and development value in purchase accounting.
SFAS&nbsp;141R amends SFAS No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes," to require the acquirer to recognize changes in
the amount of its deferred tax benefits that are recognizable because of a business combination either in income from continuing operations in the period of the combination or directly in contributed
capital, depending on the circumstances. SFAS&nbsp;141R also establishes disclosure requirements which will enable users to evaluate the nature and financial effects of the business combination.
SFAS&nbsp;141R is effective as of the beginning of the Company's 2010 fiscal year. The Company will apply SFAS&nbsp;141R to any future business combinations completed after the effective date. The
impact of the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;141R will depend on the nature, terms and size of business combinations completed after the effective date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;160 ("SFAS&nbsp;160"), "Accounting for Noncontrolling Interests," which clarifies the classification of noncontrolling interests in
consolidated statements of financial position and the accounting for and reporting of transactions between the reporting entity and holders of such noncontrolling interests. SFAS&nbsp;160 will be
effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2008. The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;160 on the Company's consolidated financial
statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March 2008, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;161 ("SFAS&nbsp;161"), "Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," which amends SFAS&nbsp;133 and expands
disclosures to include information about the fair value of derivatives, related credit risks and a company's strategies and objectives for using derivatives. SFAS&nbsp;161 is effective for fiscal
periods beginning on or after November&nbsp;15, 2008. The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;161 on its disclosures in the Company's consolidated
financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
April 2008, the FASB issued FSP No. FAS&nbsp;142-3 ("FSP FAS&nbsp;142-3"), "Determination of the Useful Life of Intangible Assets," which amends the
factors that should be considered in developing renewal or extension assumptions used to determine the useful life of a recognized intangible asset under FASB Statement No.&nbsp;142, "Goodwill and
Other Intangible Assets." The intent of FSP FAS&nbsp;142-3 is to improve the consistency between the useful life of a recognized intangible asset under FASB Statement No.&nbsp;142 and
the period of expected cash flows used to measure the fair value of the asset under SFAS&nbsp;141R. FSP FAS&nbsp;142-3 will be applied prospectively and is effective as of the
beginning of the Company's 2010 fiscal year. Where applicable, the Company will apply FSP FAS&nbsp;142-3 to future intangible assets acquired beginning in fiscal 2010. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June 2008, the FASB issued FSP No. EITF&nbsp;03-6-1 ("FSP EITF&nbsp;03-6-1"), "Determining Whether Instruments Granted in
Share-Based Payment Transactions Are Participating Securities," which requires unvested share-payment awards that contain rights to receive non-forfeitable dividends or dividend
equivalents to be included in the two-class method of computing earnings per share. FSP EITF&nbsp;03-6-1 also requires retrospective application to all periods
presented. FSP EITF&nbsp;03-6-1 is effective as of the beginning of the Company's 2010 fiscal year. Prior periods will be restated to reflect this impact in future reporting
periods. The Company expects that the adoption of FSP EITF&nbsp;03-6-1 will result in a reduction in diluted earnings per share of $0.03 for each of the years ended
January&nbsp;31, 2009 and February&nbsp;2, 2008.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do45001_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02650"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do45001_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Exchange Rate Risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately half of product sales and licensing revenue recorded for the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 were denominated in U.S.
dollars. The Company's primary exchange rate risk relates to operations in Canada, Europe and South Korea. Changes in currencies affect our earnings in various ways. For further discussion on currency
related risk, please refer to our risk factors under "ITEM 1A. Risk Factors." </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

NAME="page_dq45001_1_51"> </A>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#bg45001a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A> </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Various transactions that occur in Canada, Europe and South Korea are denominated in U.S. dollars and thus are exposed to earnings risk as a result of exchange
rate fluctuations when converted to their local functional currencies. These types of transactions include U.S. denominated purchases of merchandise and intercompany liabilities. In addition, certain
operating expenses are denominated in Swiss Francs and are exposed to earnings risk as a result of exchange rate fluctuations when converted to the functional currency. The Company enters into
derivative financial instruments, including forward exchange contracts and currency swaps, to manage exchange risk on certain anticipated foreign currency transactions. The Company does not hedge all
transactions denominated in foreign currency. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Forward Contracts Designated as Cash Flow Hedges  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company purchased U.S. dollar forward contracts in Europe and Canada totaling
US$36.0&nbsp;million and US$52.9&nbsp;million,
respectively, to hedge forecasted merchandise purchases that were designated as cash flow hedges at January&nbsp;31, 2009. During fiscal year 2009, the Company also purchased Swiss Franc/Euro
forward contracts in Europe totaling CHF18.0&nbsp;million to hedge forecasted operating expenses that were designated as cash flow hedges at January&nbsp;31, 2009. As of January&nbsp;31, 2009,
the Company had forward contracts outstanding for its European and Canadian operations of US$21.0&nbsp;million and US$38.5&nbsp;million, respectively, that are expected to mature over the next
nine months and Swiss Franc-Euro forward contracts outstanding for its European operations of CHF18.0&nbsp;million that are expected to mature over the next 12&nbsp;months. The
Company's derivative financial instruments are recorded in its consolidated balance sheet at fair value based on quoted market rates. The U.S. dollar forward contracts are used to hedge forecasted
merchandise purchases over specific months. Changes in the fair value of the U.S. dollar forward contracts designated as cash flow hedges are recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive
income within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in cost of product sales in the period which approximates the time the hedged merchandise inventory is sold. The Swiss Franc forward contracts
are used to hedge certain anticipated Swiss operating expenses over specific months. Changes in the fair value of the Swiss Franc forward contracts designated as cash flow hedges are recorded as a
component of accumulated other comprehensive income within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in SG&amp;A in the period which approximates the time the expenses are incurred. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of January&nbsp;31, 2009, accumulated other comprehensive income included an unrealized gain of approximately US$8.8&nbsp;million, net of tax, that will be recognized as a
reduction to cost of goods sold or SG&amp;A over the following 13&nbsp;months at the then current values on a pre-tax basis, which can be different than the current year-end
values. At January&nbsp;31, 2009, the unrealized net gain of the remaining open forward contracts recorded in current assets in the consolidated balance sheet was approximately
US$8.1&nbsp;million. The ineffective portion was immaterial during the year ended January&nbsp;31, 2009 and was recorded in net earnings. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company had Canadian dollar forward contracts designated as cash flow hedges to purchase US$27.0&nbsp;million with an unrealized gain recorded in the
consolidated balance sheet of approximately US$0.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes net after-tax derivative activity recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (in thousands): </FONT></P>
